thread.title: Wesfarmers chief Richard Goyder rules out career in politics
thread.title_full: Wesfarmers chief Richard Goyder rules out career in politics

title: Wesfarmers chief Richard Goyder rules out career in politics
text:
Wesfarmers managing director Richard Goyder: "I'm happy to try and make a contribution - I think I can do that better doing what I'm doing." Photo: Philip Gostelow
Wesfarmers managing director Richard Goyder has put paid to speculation he may be considering a move into politics when he retires from corporate life.
Liberal and Labor party apparatchiks eyeing Mr Goyder as a possible candidate for the seats of Curtin and Pearce, where he lives, will be disappointed to learn that the 55-year-old no longer has aspirations to enter politics.
Mr Goyder said he briefly entertained a political career in his youth, but now believed he could make a bigger contribution to society as the managing director and CEO of Wesfarmers, Australia's seventh largest company and largest private sector employer.
Working the sheep on his Toodyay farm in WA. Photo: Aaron Bunch Photographer
"I'm happy to try and make a contribution - I think I can do that better doing what I'm doing," Mr Goyder told Fairfax Media after delivering the Sir John Monash Oration at the Commonwealth Bank headquarters in Sydney on Tuesday night.
"With the exception of Malcolm Turnbull there are no business people who have made a successful transition into that role because we have different skills," he said. "I can do more as CEO of Wesfarmers."
Mr Goyder also had to consider his wife and four children.
"My wife and family have supported me for a long period of time - I don't think I'd want to throw a curve ball at them and do something I might be completely hopeless at," he added.
Mr Goyder was keeping mum about which side of politics he favoured as a teenager growing up on his family's sheep and wheat farm at Tambellup, 317 kilometres south-east of Perth.
Mr Goyder was selected by former Prime Minister Julia Gillard to chair the B20 group of business leaders advising the G20 summit last year, has employed several former Rudd Government advisers and former Labor West Australian premier Alan Carpenter is Wesfarmers' head of corporate affairs.
However, he has also worked closely with Prime Minister Tony Abbott and Treasurer Joe Hockey and has good relationships with John Howard and Peter Costello.
"I'm free enterprise but with a social conscience," he said.
Despite his stellar career at Wesfarmers and his reputation as one of Australia's most influential business leaders, Mr Goyder appears to lack the ego required to pursue a career in politics.
In his speech on Tuesday night, entitled " The Age of the God Executive Leader is over , Mr Goyder said he was still ambitious but had a "relative lack of ego".
"So I have surrounded myself with good people," he said, naming Bunnings managing director John Gillam, Coles managing director John Durkan, Kmart boss Guy Russo and Wesfarmers finance director Terry Bowen.
"High ego leaders tend to do the opposite - and they always want to be seen as in control," he said.
Mr Goyder, who marked his 10th year as Wesfarmers managing director and CEO earlier this month, is expected to stay in the job for another couple of years.
